Cara Krezek: * Indicates primary offering of a cross listed course
Planning For Success in the Neurosciences
Jennifer Smith: Foundation for success in neuroscience. Current topics in neuroscience, study skills, experiential learning opportunities and career opportunities.

Cara Krezek: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jennifer Smith: Introduction to behavioural neuroscience and biological aspects of behaviour. Basics of the structure and function of the nervous system in relation to behaviour and activities of the brain from the neuron through to interrelationships among neural systems (central and peripheral nervous system, and hormonal regulation). Topics include neuronal function, drugs and behaviour, brain plasticity and recovery from injury, sensation and perception, and the organization of the brain emphasizing human behaviour.

Cara Krezek: Lectures, 3 hours per week; lab, 3 hours per week.
Jennifer Smith: Note: material fees required. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Cara Krezek: Physiological basis of neural mechanisms relevant to human actions and cognitions such as motivation (sleep, sexual behaviour, eating), emotions and stress, learning and memory, communication and language, and thought (psychological/psychiatric disorders).
Jennifer Smith: Lectures, 3 hours per week; lab, 3 hours per week.

Cara Krezek: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jennifer Smith: Neural basis of human cognition, emphasizing contemporary methods in cognitive neuroscience. Methodology (e.g. neuroimaging), perception, memory, language, emotion, executive functions and social cognition.
Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Cara Krezek: Structure and function of nerve cells: Electrical properties of neurons, synaptic function and transmitters, neural plasticity and cellular basis of behaviour.
Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
Topics, readings and/or research chosen in consultation with a NEUR faculty member who is willing to supervise the student.
Jennifer Smith: Restriction: NEUR majors with a minimum of 8.0 overall credits and permission of the Department.

Cara Krezek: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jennifer Smith: Empirical research project chosen in consultation with a NEUR faculty member who is willing to supervise the student.

Cara Krezek: Restriction: NEUR majors with a minimum of 8.0 overall credits and permission of the Department.
Jennifer Smith: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Cara Krezek: Brain function and behaviour are through basic research on neuropsychological and neurocognitive function through clinical syndromes and cases. Topics include neural basis of perception, memory, language, motor control, emotion and executive functions. Recovery and advances in assessment, diagnosis, prognosis and treatment of such functional deficits.
Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jennifer Smith: Mechanisms of drug action and classification of psychoactive agents. Elements of pharmacokinetics (drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination) and a review of the major groups of psychoactive agents including hypnotics, analgesics, anxiolytics, antidepressants, psychostimulants and neuroleptics, emphasizing mechanisms and consequences of drug action on selected neurotransmitter systems (dopaminergic, noradrenergic,cholinergic, serotonergic).
Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Cara Krezek: Integrative approach to basic neuroscience focusing on behavioural analysis in animal models insights into brain and behaviour relations provided by the traditional and the latest techniques (e.g. stereotaxic surgery, DREADDs, viral vectors and optogenetics, transgenic organisms).
Jennifer Smith: Lectures, 2 hours per week; lab, 3 hrs alternating weeks.

Cara Krezek: Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

Jennifer Smith: Methods used in neurobiology and neurophysiology. Electro-physiological techniques, including intracellular and extracellular recording from nerve cells and muscle, and on theory and techniques for electrophysiological data acquisition. Other topics include intracellular staining, immunocyto chemistry and assay procedures.

Cara Krezek: Lectures, 2 hours per week; lab, 3 hours per week.

Jennifer Smith: Each student will undertake a limited research project under faculty supervision.

Cara Krezek: Restriction: open to NEUR majors with approval to year 4 (honours).

Jennifer Smith: Each student will undertake a detailed study of the scientific literature relevant to the topic of the honours thesis.

Cara Krezek: Restriction: open to NEUR majors with approval to year 4 (honours).

Jennifer Smith: Each student will be required to carry out two detailed studies of the scientific literature under faculty supervision.

Jennifer Smith: Relations among the hormones of the endocrine system, the nervous system and behaviour; the involvement of hormones in sexual behaviour, the mechanisms of stress and cognition; relevant research methodologies.
Note: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
